sentences.text: Presidential elections were held in Sri Lanka on 21 September 2024. Incumbent President of Sri Lanka|president Ranil Wickremesinghe ran for re-election as an Independent politician|independent candidate, making him the first sitting president to run for re-election since Mahinda Rajapaksa in 2015 Sri Lankan presidential election|2015. Other prominent candidates included Leader of the Opposition (Sri Lanka)|Leader of the Opposition Sajith Premadasa, Anura Kumara Dissanayake of the National People's Power|NPP, and Namal Rajapaksa, son of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa.

sentences.text: The election was a three-way contest between Wickremesinghe, Premadasa and Dissanayake. For the first time in a Sri Lankan presidential election, no candidate received a majority of the vote. Dissanayake was in first place with 42%, followed by Premadasa with 33%. Incumbent president Wickremesinghe finished third, receiving only 17% of the vote. As no candidate received a majority, second preference votes were counted. The following day, Dissanayake was declared the winner with 56% of the vote after second preferences had been taken into account. He was inaugurated on 23 September.

sentences.text: The election signified a major political realignment in Sri Lanka. Dissanayake's victory was the first time a Third party (politics)|third-party candidate was elected president. This was also the first election where neither of the top two candidates were endorsed by the United National Party or the Sri Lanka Freedom Party.

This triggered an 2022 Sri Lankan presidential election|indirect presidential election via Parliament a week later, to elect a successor according to the Article 40 of the Constitution. Ranil Wickremesinghe, who had been appointed as Prime Minister of Sri Lanka|Prime Minister by Rajapaksa just two months earlier, received the most votes and was sworn in as the 9th President of Sri Lanka on 21 July 2022.

sentences.text: Article 40 of the Constitution of Sri Lanka states that "Any person so succeeding to the office of President shall hold office only for the unexpired period of the term of office of the President vacating office. President Wickremesinghe's term is due to expire on 17 November 2024.

sentences.text: Discussion surrounding the 2024 election had been a major topic since the beginning of the year. The Election Commission of Sri Lanka|Election Commission stated that the election had to be held between 17 September and 16 October, as required by the Constitution. On 26 July, the Election Commission issued a The Sri Lanka Gazette|Gazette notification declaring that the election would be held on 21 September 2024, with nominations for candidates to be submitted by 15 August. The commission chose to hold the election on a Saturday, stating that this would help ensure a high voter turnout. On the same day, Ranil Wickremesinghe announced his candidacy for a second term as president, running as an Independent politician|independent candidate.<ref name="AJ-26.07.2024" /><ref name="DH-27.07.2024" />

sentences.text: The President of Sri Lanka is elected through a system of limited ranked voting. Voters can express up to three ranked preferences for the presidency. If no candidate receives more than 50% of all valid votes in the first count, all candidates except the two who received the highest number of votes are eliminated. The second and third preference votes of the eliminated candidates are then redistributed to the remaining two candidates until one of them secures an outright majority.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://elections.gov.lk/web/wp-content/uploads/publication/acts/15-1981_E.pdf |title=Presidential Elections Act, No.15 of 1981 |publisher=Election Commission of Sri Lanka |date= |accessdate=24 August 2024 |archive-date=3 August 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240803060705/https://elections.gov.lk/web/wp-content/uploads/publication/acts/15-1981_E.pdf |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: In practice, this system had seen no use. Every presidential election since the first in 1982 Sri Lankan presidential election|1982 had resulted in a candidate from one of the major parties or alliances winning an outright majority in the first count. Consequently, most voters choose to mark only one candidate on their ballots, and many are either unaware that they can rank multiple candidates or choose not to exercise that prerogative.

sentences.text: The Election Commission outlined the voting procedure on 30 August 2024, detailing the ranked voting system due to the multiple candidates contesting the presidential election, ensuring voters were informed on how to cast and submit their ballots. Voting began at 13,134 polling stations nationwide at 7:00 AM Sri Lanka Standard Time|SLST on 21 September and closed at 4:00 PM SLST.

sentences.text: The Election Commission announced the dates and locations for postal voting in a media release on 29 August 2024. This facility is available only to pre-approved officials engaged in election duties. Postal voting was conducted on 4, 5, 6, 11, and 12 September, strictly according to the provided schedule.<ref name="ajstake"/>

sentences.text: Due to the larger size of the ballot papers, the Election Commission has opted to use cardboard ballot boxes instead of traditional wooden ones. These boxes will be available in three sizes. A combination of wooden and cardboard ballot boxes was used in the 2019 Sri Lankan presidential election and the 2020 Sri Lankan parliamentary election.

sentences.text: To further ensure security, the government imposed a liquor ban on the weekend of 21 to 22 September and deployed more than 63,000 police officers to secure polling stations and counting centres. It also banned the holding of victory rallies or celebrations until a week after the results were announced. A nighttime curfew was also declared after the end of voting, which was lifted at noon on 22 September.

sentences.text:
{{Further|List of political parties in Sri Lanka}}
By the end of candidate registration on 15 August, the Election Commission had accepted a total of 39 applications for the presidential election, the highest number ever recorded for a presidential election in Sri Lanka. One candidate, Mohamed Illiyas, died of a heart attack prior to the election. His name on the ballot was not replaced. Despite the record number of candidates, none were female.

sentences.text: One of the main reasons for the proliferation of candidates is the low election deposit required to contest – Rs. 50,000 (US$170) for party candidates and Rs. 75,000 (US$250) for independent candidates. These amounts that have remained unchanged since the introduction of presidential elections in 1982.

sentences.text: The first presidential debate was scheduled for 7 September 2024, hosted by the March 12 Movement. Four candidates, Sajith Premadasa, Namal Rajapaksa, Dilith Jayaweera, and P. Ariyanethiran, confirmed their participation. The debate took place at the Bandaranaike Memorial International Conference Hall (BMICH) and was broadcast live on mainstream television and social media platforms. However, despite initial confirmations, only Dilith Jayaweera attended the debate.

sentences.text: Following an invitation from the Election Commission of Sri Lanka, the European External Action Service (EEAS) of the European Union (EU) will deploy an Election Observation Mission (EOM) to observe the Presidential Election scheduled for 21 September.

sentences.text: The Election Commission further announced that representatives from 12 countries have been invited to observe the upcoming election. Among those participating are South Asian countries such as India, Nepal, Bangladesh, Pakistan, and the Maldives, as well as a Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth Commonwealth Observer Groups|observer group (COG) and representatives from the Asian Network for Free Elections|Asian Election Observation Network.

sentences.text: The Election Commission, through a Gazette notification (Gazette Extraordinary – No. 2397/66 on 16 August 2024), set an Campaign finance|expenditure cap of Rs. 109 per voter for the 2024 presidential election. As a result, each candidate is now permitted to spend a maximum of Rs. 1.8 billion (Rs. 1,868,298,586). These regulations have been enforced under the Regulation of Election Expenditure Act, No. 3 of 2023, which was certified on 24 January 2023.

sentences.text: The following nationwide presidential poll was conducted by the IHP. The poll ranked Sajith Premadasa, Anura Kumara Dissanayake, Ranil Wickremesinghe, and a generic SLPP candidate. All polls conducted before Namal Rajapaksa announced his candidacy on 7 August, including the ''IHP Multilevel Regression with Poststratification|MRP Presidential Election Update June 2024'' released on 1 August, did not account for his entry.

sentences.text:
;January 2024
In the Institute for Health Policy (IHP) Sri Lanka Opinion Tracker Survey (SLOTS) polling, all major party candidates continued to have negative favourability ratings. The net favourability rating of Anura Kumara Dissanayake increased by 12 points to −10, while the favourability ratings of Sajith Premadasa and incumbent President Ranil Wickremesinghe each decreased by 9 points, to −53 and −77, respectively.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://ihp.lk/press-releases/ak-dissanayake-sees-favourability-ratings-improve-other-party-leaders-see-declines |title=AK Dissanayake sees favourability ratings improve, but other party leaders see declines in January 2024 |publisher=Institute for Health Policy |date=23 February 2024 |accessdate=27 August 2024 |archive-date=15 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240415051256/https://ihp.lk/press-releases/ak-dissanayake-sees-favourability-ratings-improve-other-party-leaders-see-declines |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text:
;March 2024
In IHP SLOTS polling, the net favourability rating of Sajith Premadasa increased by 30 points to −30 in March compared to the previous month, while the favourability ratings of Anura Kumara Dissanayake and President Ranil Wickremesinghe remained relatively unchanged at −24 (down 2 points) and −78 (up 1 point), respectively.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://ihp.lk/press-releases/favourability-sajith-premadasa-improves-march-2024-ak-dissanayake-continues-lead |title=Favourability of Sajith Premadasa improves in March 2024, But AK Dissanayake continues to lead |publisher=Institute for Health Policy |date=18 April 2024 |accessdate=27 August 2024 |archive-date=28 May 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240528102951/https://ihp.lk/press-releases/favourability-sajith-premadasa-improves-march-2024-ak-dissanayake-continues-lead |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text:
;July 2024
In the IHP SLOTS polling conducted in July 2024, the net favourability rating of Anura Kumara Dissanayake rose by 29 points from June, reaching +3. President Ranil Wickremesinghe's favourability improved by 40 points to −24, surpassing that of Sajith Premadasa. Sajith Premadasa's favourability rating changed little, shifting from −42 in June to −44 in July.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://ihp.lk/press-releases/ak-dissanayakes-and-president-wickremesinghes-favourability-ratings-largely-improved |title=AK Dissanayake's and President Wickremesinghe's favourability ratings largely improved in July 2024 |publisher=Institute for Health Policy |date=27 August 2024 |accessdate=27 August 2024 |archive-date=27 August 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240827055036/https://ihp.lk/press-releases/ak-dissanayakes-and-president-wickremesinghes-favourability-ratings-largely-improved |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text:
;August 2024
In the IHP SLOTS polling for August 2024, the net favourability rating of Sajith Premadasa improved to −32, a 10-point increase compared to July. Meanwhile, Anura Kumara Dissanayake and President Ranil Wickremesinghe saw their favourability ratings drop to −21 (a decrease of 16 points) and −33 (a decrease of 4 points), respectively. The favourability rating of Namal Rajapaksa, stood at −89.

sentences.text: While counting was still underway, foreign minister Ali Sabry (Sri Lankan politician)|Ali Sabry congratulated Dissanayake, citing his strong showing in the results. The test match between New Zealand cricket team in Sri Lanka in 2024–25#1st Test|Sri Lanka and New Zealand featured a rest day due to the election. It was the first time in sixteen years since a test match had a rest day.

sentences.text: SJB MP Harsha de Silva congratulated Dissanayake. The Tamil National Alliance, which had endorsed Premadasa, congratulated Dissanayake for his "impressive win" without relying on "racial or religious chauvinism". Ranil Wickremesinghe also congratulated Dissanayake.<ref name="inauguaral"/>

sentences.text: The International Monetary Fund congratulated Dissanayake and said it was ready to discuss the future of the economic recovery plan.

sentences.text: Dissanayake attributed his victory to the "collective effort" of voters. He was sworn in as president on 23 September. Parliament was dissolved by Dissanayake the next day, and 2024 Sri Lankan parliamentary election|early parliamentary elections were called on 14 November.

sentences.text:
* {{Flag|Australia}}: High Commissioner Paul Stephens congratulated Dissanayake and said he looked forward to strengthening the relationship between the two countries.
* {{Flag|Canada}}: The High Commission of Canada in Sri Lanka released a statement congratulating Dissanayake.
* {{Flag|Cuba}}: First Secretary of the Communist Party of Cuba|First Secretary Miguel Díaz-Canel congratulated Dissanayake and ratified the will to strengthen ties between Cuba and Sri Lanka.
* {{Flag|France}}: President of France|President Emmanuel Macron congratulated Dissanayake.
* {{Flag|India}}: Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister Narendra Modi congratulated Dissanayake, expressing his desire to work with the President-elect to strengthen their cooperation.
* {{Flag|Japan}}: Ambassador Mizukoshi Hideaki released a statement congratulating Dissanayake, noting a "significant moment in Sri Lanka's journey as the country continues to recover from its economic challenges."
* {{Flag|Maldives}}: President of the Maldives|President Mohamed Muizzu released a post congratulating Dissanayake, saying he hoped to "strengthen the historic friendship between the Maldives and Sri Lanka."
* {{Flag|New Zealand}}: Minister of Foreign Affairs (New Zealand)|Minister of Foreign Affairs Winston Peters congratulated Dissanayake and praised the safe, fair, and free election conducted.
* {{Flag|Pakistan}}: Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif congratulated Dissanayake, wishing him success.
* {{Flag|Saudi Arabia}}: Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques Salman of Saudi Arabia|King Salman wished Dissanayake success and the people of Sri Lanka further progress and prosperity.
* {{Flag|United Arab Emirates}}: President of the United Arab Emirates|President Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan wished Dissanayake success and said he looked forward to strengthen their countries' relations.
* {{Flag|United States}}: President of the United States|President Joe Biden congratulated Dissanayake and also noted that Sri Lankans voted in a "fair, free, and peaceful" election.
* {{Flag|United Kingdom}}: High Commissioner Andrew Patrick and Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Indo-Pacific|Minister of State for Indo-Pacific Catherine West both released statements congratulating Dissanayake and looking forward to working with him.
